description:
Aspergillus ellipticus CBS 707.79 is a species of filamentous fungus belonging to the genus Aspergillus. This species was first isolated and identified in 1979 and is maintained in the Centraalbureau voor Schimmelcultures (CBS) culture collection.

Aspergillus ellipticus is known to produce conidiophores (asexual reproductive structures) that are typically tall and slender, with globose vesicles at the apex. The conidial heads (spore-bearing structures) are usually elliptical or oblong in shape, which is a distinguishing characteristic of this species.

Morphologically, the colonies of A. ellipticus on agar media can appear velvety or powdery, with a range of colors from white to various shades of green, depending on the stage of sporulation. Microscopically, the conidiophores, vesicles, and conidia (asexual spores) exhibit characteristic features that aid in the identification and differentiation of this species from other Aspergillus taxa.

The genetic and molecular features of A. ellipticus CBS 707.79 have been studied and used for taxonomic classification and phylogenetic analysis within the Aspergillus genus. This information contributes to the understanding of the diversity and evolutionary relationships within this important group of fungi.
